title: SHO energy - block-spring amplitude from x0 and v0

content.question: A block on a horizontal surface is attached to one end of a horizontal spring, and the other end of the spring is fixed in place. The block, which is free to move in the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction along the surface with negligible friction, oscillates in simple harmonic motion. The block’s mass is <math alttext="2.0 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></math>, and its motion has an oscillation period of <math alttext="2.0 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math>. When the block is <math alttext="0.30 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>30</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> from the equilibrium position, it has a speed of <math alttext="0.50 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></math>. What is the amplitude of the block’s motion?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
